stattutor_problem.title: Cell Phones
stattutor_problem.background:
College students at a large state university completed a survey about their academic and personal life. Questions ranged from "How many credits are you registered for this semester?" to "Would you define yourself as a vegetarian?" Four sections of an introductory statistics course were chosen at random from all the sections of introductory statistics courses offered at the university in the semester when the survey was conducted, and the 312 students who completed the survey were students registered in one of the four chosen sections.

In this exercise, we will use a subset of variables from the survey and use the collected data to answer three questions. Note that (1) these are real data, and (2) the symbol * in the worksheet means that this observation is not available (this is known as a "missing value").

variable.name: Credits
variable.description: Number of credits the student is registered for

variable.name: Exer
variable.description: Time (in minutes) spent exercising in a typical day

variable.name: Sleep
variable.description: Time (in hours) spent sleeping in a typical day

variable.name: Veg
variable.description: Are you a vegetarian (yes, no, some)

variable.name: Cell
variable.description: Do you own a cell phone (yes, no)

cdf_question.text: Out of the first ten students in the datafile, how many did better on the verbal portion of the SAT compared to the math portion?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single student, so the first ten rows represent the first ten students. Look at the Math and Verbal columns and count how many of the first ten students did better on the verbal portion of the SAT

If you look at the first ten students (rows) in the dataset, you'll see that six of the students did better on the verbal portion of the SAT than on the math portion. These are students 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 9.

cdf_question.text: Out of the first ten students in the datafile, how many are at least somewhat vegetarian?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single student, so the first ten rows represent the first ten students. Look at the Veg column and count how many of the first ten students are at least somewhat vegetarian.
If you look at the first ten students (rows) in the dataset, you'll see that three of the students reported being at least somewhat vegetarian. These are students 5, 6, and 8.

cdf_question.text: How many hours does the first junior in the datafile who does not own a cell phone spend sleeping in a typical day?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single student. Scroll down the dataset and look for the first junior (Year=3) who does not own a cell phone (Cell=no), and report the number of hours this student spends sleeping in a typical day.
If you look at the first ten students (rows) in the dataset, you'll see that the first junior who does not own a cell phone is student #18. This student sleeps 6.5 hours in a typical day.

our_answer.text: The 312 students who participated in the study were chosen via cluster sampling, where 4 clusters of students were chosen at random, and all the students in these four clusters are the sample. The resulting sample can be considered to be a random sample of the entire "population" of students who take the statistics course at this university.

main_question.text: The mean verbal SAT score of all the students in this university is 580. Is this also the case for all stat students at this university? Note that verbal SAT scores in the U.S. have a standard deviation of 111.

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and discovering how the verbal SAT scores of stat students compare with the university mean, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: Since students from a variety of majors are required to take a statistics course, there is no reason to believe that the students who participated in this study have different verbal skills (as measured by verbal SAT scores) than the general population at this university.
The distribution of the verbal SAT scores is roughly symmetric, has a mean of roughly 597, and standard deviation of about 78.
The distribution of the verbal SAT scores is roughly symmetric, has a mean of roughly 597, and standard deviation of about 78.
Here is the Excel output:
The distribution of the verbal SAT scores is roughly symmetric, has a mean of roughly 597, and standard deviation of about 78.
The distribution of the verbal SAT scores is roughly symmetric and has a mean of roughly 597.
The distribution of the verbal SAT scores is roughly symmetric, has a mean of roughly 597, and standard deviation of about 78.

determine_mfa.test: one sample z-test for the mean

our_answer.text: The test statistic is z = 2.55 and the p-value is .011 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
The test statistic is z = 2.55 and the p-value is .011 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
Here is the Excel output:
The test statistic is z = 2.55 and the p-value is .011 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
The test statistic is z = 2.55 and the p-value is .011 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
The test statistic is z = 2.55 and the p-value is .011 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.

consider_results.question: What do the results you got indicate about whether the verbal SAT scores of stat students differ from the scores of students of the entire student body at this university?

our_answer.text:
• In the exploratory analysis we found that the mean verbal SAT score in the sample of stat students is 597, which is quite different from 580. The question is: Are the results significantly different from 580?

  • Indeed, the formal statistical test produced a p-value of .011, indicating that the data provide sufficient evidence to reject Ho and to conclude that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students is significantly different than 580, the mean score for the entire student body in this university.

thought_question.question: Since H<sub>0</sub> was rejected in this case, all we can conclude is that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students is not 580. It would be worthwhile, then to supplement this conclusion by using a 95% confidence interval. Using the output, state the 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students, and interpret it in context.

Since H0 was rejected in this case, all we can conclude is that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students is not 580. It would be worthwhile, then to supplement this conclusion by using a 95% confidence interval. Using the output, state the 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students, and interpret it in context.

To do this in StatCrunch:

  • Choose Stat -> Z statistics -> One sample -> with data.
  • Under 'Select Columns', choose the relevant variable.
  • Next to 'Std. Dev.', enter the value of the standard deviation.
  • Press Next.
  • Select Confidence Interval.
  • Next to 'Level', enter 0.95.
  • Press Calculate.

Since H0 was rejected in this case, all we can conclude is that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students is not 580. It would be worthwhile, then to supplement this conclusion by using a 95% confidence interval. Calculate the 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students, and interpret it in context.

To do this in Excel:

  • To calculate the confidence interval, we use the Excel formula CONFIDENCE(alpha, standard deviation, n).
  • Since we want to find the 95% confidence interval, we use 0.05 for alpha. We already know that the standard deviation is 111 and n is 286.
  • Confidence intervals are typically reported as a range, where the range is (the sample mean minus confidence interval value we just calculated) to (the sample mean plus the confidence interval value we just calculated).

Since H0 was rejected in this case, all we can conclude is that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students is not 580. It would be worthwhile, then to supplement this conclusion by using 95% confidence interval. Calculate the 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students, and interpret it in context.

To do this in R, use the following commands for the upper and lower bounds of the confidence interval:
  • lower=qnorm(0.025, mean=596.7, sd=111/sqrt(286)); lower
  • upper=qnorm(0.975, mean=596.7, sd=111/sqrt(286)); upper

Since H0 was rejected in this case, all we can conclude is that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students is not 580. It would be worthwhile, then to supplement this conclusion by using 95% confidence interval. Calculate the 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students, and interpret it in context.

Create a confidence interval for the population mean (sigma known)

  • Choose STAT/TESTS/7:ZInterval
  • Choose DATA by using arrows to highlight DATA, then pressing ENTER.
  • s: 111 (population standard deviation is given in the problem)
  • List: Choose L2 (2ND/2) for verbal SAT scores
  • Freq:1
  • C-Level:0.95 (confidence level is given in the problem)
  • Choose CALCULATE, then press ENTER.

our_answer.text: The 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is roughly (584, 610). We are therefore 95% confident that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is between 584 and 610. Note that the entire confidence interval (representing the plausible values for the mean verbal SAT score of stats students at this university) does not include 580, which is consistent with the fact that the Ho was rejected.

The 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is roughly (584, 610). We are therefore 95% confident that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is between 584 and 610. Note that the entire confidence interval (representing the plausible values for the mean verbal SAT score of stats students at this university) does not include 580, which is consistent with the fact that the Ho was rejected.

The 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is roughly (584, 610). We are therefore 95% confident that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is between 584 and 610. Note that the entire confidence interval (representing the plausible values for the mean verbal SAT score of stats students at this university) does not include 580, which is consistent with the fact that the Ho was rejected.

The 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is roughly (584, 610). We are therefore 95% confident that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is between 584 and 610. Note that the entire confidence interval (representing the plausible values for the mean verbal SAT score of stats students at this university) does not include 580, which is consistent with the fact that the Ho was rejected.

The 95% confidence interval for the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is roughly (584, 610). We are therefore 95% confident that the mean verbal SAT score of stat students at this university is between 584 and 610. Note that the entire confidence interval (representing the plausible values for the mean verbal SAT score of stats students at this university) does not include 580, which is consistent with the fact that the Ho was rejected.

thought_question.hint: Find the 95% CI in the output, and recall that it represents an interval for which we are 95% sure that it contains the population mean of interest.

our_answer.text:
• The results are different from what we had originally expected. A possible explanation is that students who are required to take this stat class are from certain majors which are more competitive.

  • These results might be useful to the university for future admission purposes.

main_question.text: Based on a recent study, roughly 80% of college students in the U.S. own a cell phone. Do the data provide evidence that the proportion of students who own cell phones in this university is lower than the national figure?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and exploring how cell phone ownership among college students at this university compares with college students in general, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: There is no reason to believe that students at this university are different from the entire population of students in the U.S. with respect to whether or not they own a cell phone.
Roughly 78% of the students in the sample own a cell phone.
Roughly 78% of the students in the sample own a cell phone.
Here is the Excel output:
Roughly 78% of the students in the sample own a cell phone. Note that we did not include the 2 students who failed to respond to this question, and took our percentages out of the 310 who responded.
Roughly 78% of the students in the sample own a cell phone.
Roughly 78% of the students in the sample own a cell phone. Note that we had 310 out of the 312 students in our sample respond to this question.

determine_mfa.test: one sample z-test for the proportion

thought_question.question: Explain why the relevant test for this question (which you chose above) can be reliably used?

our_answer.text: Both conditions under which we can reliably use the z-test for the population proportion are met:(i) The sample is random (recall that the sampling method used is cluster sampling)(ii) n = 312, and Po = .8 and so 312(.8) = 249.6 â‰¥ 10 and also 312(1-.8) = 62.4 â‰¥ 10.

thought_question.hint: Recall that the two conditions that need to be satisfied are (i) Having a random sample and (ii) n*Po and n*(1-Po) both need to be at least 10

our_answer.text: The test statistic is z = -.71, and the p-value is .239 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is z = -.71, and the p-value is .239 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
Here is the Excel output:
The test statistic is z = -.71, and the p-value is .239 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is z = -.71, and the p-value is .239 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is z = -.71, and the p-value is .239 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.

consider_results.question: What do the results you got indicate about the proportion of students at this university who own cell phones?

our_answer.text:
• In the exploratory analysis we found that roughly 78% of the sampled students own a cell phone.

  • The formal statistical test assessed that even though 78% is less than 80%, this does not provide enough evidence to conclude that the proportion of students at this university who own a cell phone is less than .8 (which is the national proportion).

• The results are consistent with what we initially expected.

  • We found no relevant or meaningful way to use this information for a practical purpose. It is merely interesting information.

main_question.text: Adults in the U.S. average 7 hours of sleep a night. Is this also the mean for all stat students at this university?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and exploring the sleeping habits of stat students at this university compared to adults in general, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: It would be reasonable to expect that the mean number of sleep hours of students will be lower due to studying or partying...

The distribution of the number of sleep hours is roughly symmetric but has some low and high outliers. The distribution is centered at around 7 (median = 7), has a range of 12, and an IQR of 1.5. Even though it's the case that when outliers are present we focus on the median as a measure of center, it should be mentioned that the mean is roughly 7.2, which is larger than the national mean of U.S. adults (7).

The distribution of the number of sleep hours is roughly symmetric but has some low and high outliers. The distribution is centered at around 7 (median = 7), has a range of 12, and an IQR of 1.5. Even though it's the case that when outliers are present we focus on the median as a measure of center, it should be mentioned that the mean is roughly 7.2, which is larger than the national mean of U.S. adults (7).
Here is the Excel output:

The distribution of the number of sleep hours is roughly symmetric but has some outliers. The distribution is centered at around 7 (median = 7), has a range of 12, and an IQR of 1.5. Even though it's the case that when outliers are present we focus on the median as a measure of center, it should be mentioned that the mean is roughly 7.2, which is larger than the national mean of U.S. adults (7).

The distribution of the number of sleep hours is roughly symmetric but has some low and high outliers. The distribution is centered at around 7 (median = 7), has a range of 12, and an IQR of 1.5. Even though it's the case that when outliers are present we focus on the median as a measure of center, it should be mentioned that the mean is roughly 7.2, which is larger than the national mean of U.S. adults (7).

The distribution of the number of sleep hours is roughly symmetric but has some low and high outliers. The distribution is centered at around 7 (median = 7), has a range of 12, and an IQR of 1.5. Even though it's the case that when outliers are present we focus on the median as a measure of center, it should be mentioned that the mean is roughly 7.2, which is larger than the national mean of U.S. adults (7).

determine_mfa.test: one sample t-test for the mean

thought_question.question: Explain why the relevant test for this question (which you chose above) can be reliably used even though the histogram of our variable (hours of sleep in a typical day) does not follow a normal distribution.

our_answer.text: The reason that we can use the t-test reliably is the fact the sample size of n = 312 > 30 is large enough.
The test statistic is t = 2.41 and the p-value is .017 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
The test statistic is t = 2.41 and the p-value is .017 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
Here is the Excel output:
The test statistic is t = 2.41 and the p-value is .017 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
The test statistic is t = 2.41 and the p-value is .017 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.
The test statistic is t = 2.41 and the p-value is .017 < .05, indicating that Ho can be rejected.

consider_results.question: What do the results indicate about the mean number of sleep hours of stats students relative to the national mean of U.S. adults which is 7?

our_answer.text:
• The mean number sleep hours in our sample was found to be roughly 7.2, which is slightly higher than the national average.

  • The formal statistical test produced a p-value of .017 indicating that this sample result provides enough evidence to reject Ho and conclude that the mean number of sleep hours of stat students is significantly different from the national mean for U.S. adults, which is 7 hours of sleep.

thought_question.question: Since H<sub>0</sub> was rejected in this case, estimate the mean number of hours a stat student sleeps in a typical night with a 95% confidence interval (see output), and interpret the interval in context.

Since H0 was rejected in this case, estimate the mean number of hours a stat student sleeps in a typical night with a 95% confidence interval (see output), and interpret the interval in context.

To do this in StatCrunch:

  • Choose Stat -> T statistics -> One sample -> with data.
  • Under 'Select Columns', choose the relevant variable.
  • Press Next.
  • Select Confidence Interval.
  • Next to 'Level', enter 0.95.
  • Press Calculate.

Since Ho was rejected in this case, estimate the mean number of hours a stat student sleeps in a typical night with a 95% confidence interval, and interpret the interval in context.

To do this in Excel:

  • To calculate the confidence interval, we use the Excel formula CONFIDENCE(alpha, standard deviation, n).
  • Since we want to find the 95% confidence interval, we use 0.05 for alpha. We already know that the standard deviation is 1.42 and n is 312.
  • Confidence intervals are typically reported as a range, where the range is (the sample mean minus the confidence interval value we just calculated) to (the sample mean plus the confidence interval value we just calculated).

Since H0 was rejected in this case, estimate the mean number of hours a stat student sleeps in a typical night with a 95% confidence interval (see output), and interpret the interval in context.

To do this in R, use the command t.test(data$Sleep)$conf.int

Since H0 was rejected in this case, estimate the mean number of hours a stat student sleeps in a typical night with a 95% confidence interval (see output), and interpret the interval in context.

Create a confidence interval for population mean (sigma unknown)

  • Choose STAT/TESTS/7:
  • Choose DATA by using arrows to highlight DATA, then pressing ENTER.
  • List: Choose L3 (2ND/3) for hours slept
  • Freq:1
  • C-Level:0.95 (confidence level given in problem)
  • Choose CALCULATE, then press ENTER.

our_answer.text: The 95% confidence interval for the mean number of sleep hours of stat students at this university is roughly (7.04, 7.35). We are therefore 95% confident that the mean number of sleep hours of stat students at this university is between 7.04 and 7.35. Note that the entire confidence interval (representing the plausible values for the mean number of sleep hours of stats students at this university) does not include 7, which is consistent with the fact that H<sub>0</sub> was rejected.

The 95% confidence interval for the mean number of sleep hours of stat students at this university is roughly (7.04, 7.35). Note that the entire confidence interval (representing the plausible values for the mean number of sleep hours of stats students at this university) does not include 7, which is consistent with the fact that H<sub>0</sub> was rejected.

thought_question.hint: Find the 95% CI in the output, and recall that it represents an interval for which we are 95% sure that it contains the population mean of interest.

our_answer.text:
• The results are actually very different from what we initially expected. Interesting...

  • Since many stats students are teenagers and teenagers need more sleep than adults, students should be advised to make sure they are getting enough sleep to be able to do their best at the university.

The three questions we answered in this exercise have to do with evaluating some characteristics of stats students at the university where the study was done relative to some other larger groups of students. We found that the mean verbal SAT score of the stats students is significantly different from that of the entire student body at the university, and that the proportion of stats students who own a cell phone is not significantly lower than the proportion for all college students in the nation. In addition we found that the mean number of sleep hours of stats students at this university is significantly different from that of U.S. adults.

• The questions in this StatTutor only dealt with one variable rather than how one variable affected another. Thus, making causal conclusions is not appropriate.

  • The cluster sampling design produces a random sample, and therefore we can generalize our results to the entire "population" of students at this university who are taking this stats class. Again, since stats students have many different majors, we can probably generalize the results to the entire student body at this university.
